I want to introduce myself I'm a Clement

we are a company that started in Palo

allows companies to analyze metrics at
scale and also allow them to monitor
whatever that they are doing your
machines application software business
metrics and whatnot we have a lot of
very exciting customers on our journey

you today we also have lyft
British Gas Intuit workday just very
illustrious SAS companies and a company
at scale that that worked with us
closely as we developed our platform for

announced it was announced that we were
getting acquired by VMware and so we are
now still a kind of startup group within
within VMware as we start to get a more
exposure to the larger customer base of
VMware and obviously a lot of them are
in this journey of getting into the
cloud getting into hybrid cloud and we
are there to help them along that path
so just a very quick overview on what is
on what is way front so wave front is a
is a SAS platform as I said so it lives
on AWS itself and it allows any person
in a company to send metrics into the
system so the metric could be coming
from machines it could be coming from
AWS infrastructure it could be coming
from business logic it could be coming
from an external service and all of that
as long as it is time series data as
long as you could track it as long as it
has a numerical value and a timestamp
you could send it to wave front so wave
front is a
very is a highly scalable platform that
could take up to millions of points per
second and not only can you ingest it
into the platform we also have a query
language that allows you to query that
data quickly at scale back to the user
so that you could visualize it and alert
on top of it so again I mentioned box
has been an amazing partner along this
journey so I want to welcome Dimitri who
is a senior staff sre at box who has
been with us on this journey to talk
about how they leveraged way front on
their journey to AWS so with that
Dimitri thank you :

hi Dimitri Murata's senior staff site
reliability engineer with box you're
gonna talk a little bit about what's
been going on in our journey to the
cloud leveraging wavefront is a big part
of our journey and getting there so just
briefly about box we're a cloud content
management company that in Pryor's it
empowers enterprises to revolutionize
how they work by securely connecting
their people information and
applications we have approximately 52
million users and over 74,000 paying
organizations our SRA team is about 20
people and we're responsible for the
production infrastructure tooling and
support of about another 400 engineers
so before talking about wavefront
let me first reveal some of the problems
the Box was running into with our
pre-existing open source solution we
were leveraging an open source tool
called open TS DB which provided pretty
rudimentary graphing and pretty
rudimentary instrumentation when we
started trying to manage the site using
this tool we ran into three major
problems the first one was scale like
how many metrics can this thing handle
second was capacity again how many
metrics but also the read and writes the
size of the database over time and the
third problem we had was with uptime we
simply couldn't keep the system up to
such an extent that we could use it as a
fundamental part of the Box
infrastructure
so enter wavefront
I think of wavefront as a metrics SAS
company for us that means we no longer
have to run any of this infrastructure
we simply have to instrument our code
instrument our infrastructure and ship
our metrics into wavefront and then they
handle all of the aggregation all the
retention all the dashboarding query
languages so that we don't have to
that's a tremendously powerful lift up
for box because these are not things
that we're particularly strong at doing
and that's their sole purpose for
existing so some examples of things that
were able to do are like spot and
reserved instance pricing OS metrics all
the basics application performance and
we have about 800 total dashboards for a
team of about 400 engineers so that
gives you an idea of like how widely
adopted way friend has been for us at
box if you think about the key benefits
that wavefront brings to box I would
summarize them as like real-time
visibility everybody running a
production infrastructure needs to have
real-time visibility into their
application into their infrastructure in
order to run their business the
dashboards are extremely powerful and
I'll show you a couple examples in the
next slides they by outsourcing this
chunk of our responsibility to wavefront
it allowed us to focus on higher
leverage activities that were more
germane to our customer base and to get
ourselves out of the undifferentiated
heavy lifting to quote Verner Vogel's so
it's been hugely impactful for my
perception to engineer satisfaction
every time I talk to engineers at box
many times they'll have way front
dashboards up on their screens they're
in the hallways they're part and parcel
of how we troubleshoot and fix the site
in real time so it's really become
integral to the way that box manages our
infrastructure and our service here's an
example of one of the dashboards this
happen to be one that I created the
thing that I like about this type of
dashboard is that it's available to
anybody inside the company so we can all
be looking literally at the same page
and these are real-time stats that are
updated as change has happened in AWS
this is showing us things like what
percentage of infrastructure is running
on AWS versus on-premises what is the
throughput and CP utilization of all of
our different server types what does the
network look like etc so it's super
handy to have this all-in-one dashboard
that you can create kind of from scratch
yourself here's another dashboard that
we use to leverage spot pricing so it
turns out that Amazon didn't expose this
metric but they could expose an API call
so we wrote a simple shell script to go
out and parse the spot pricing for all
the instance types that we were using we
were able to send that data into wave
front and then visualize it with these
little dots on the graph to show us
spikes in pricing or to explain why spot
instances may have been terminated
prematurely it cetera another super
awesome thing for us is to be able to do
capacity planning using graphs I think
the tendency is like if you go around
and ask an engineer ok next quarter do
you want 10 new servers or do you want
20 the answer that will be invariably 20
and if you do that quarter after quarter
after quarter systems just start to
accrue and get way too big and wait to
cost and efficient contrast that with a
data driven approach where an engineer
the manager the capacity team whoever is
concerned can sit down and look at an
actual graph of how much of the capacity
that we've given you have you
historically used and how much do you
see that growing over time that's a much
healthier place to have a capacity
discussion from rather than a drive-by
conversation with an engineer who's just
going to say you know basically give me
more so capacity planning has been
hugely impactful for us by leveraging
wavefront I think another thing that's
really gets highlighted by the fact that
we have such fine grained and detailed
information is that we can spot trends
in our data here I'm showing the number
of instances over time that we use to
manage one of the box services
and you'll see the data is pretty spikey
now I know this data intimately well
because it's my data you probably have
similar graphs of your own data but what
stands out to me in this graph is that
there are basically five peaks
throughout the workweek corresponding to
the five workdays and then on the
weekends the traffic starts to fall down
and it's not as not as high so we can
take advantage of that fact and use
things like spot instances dynamically
auto scaling auto scaling groups to use
the metrics that are coming from our
system to help drive the system itself
so you have a feedback loop and I think
that's a super power that you get if you
spend the time to instrument your code
design your services and leverage things
that Amazon or other cloud providers
maybe provide to you to right-size your
infrastructure in real time and keep
your costs under control we've had a
pretty strong adoption of wavefront
throughout box one of my favorite things
about this slide is that I think myself
or another engineer and the team created
this this slide and then I found it in a
slide deck getting shown to the
executives in the company they didn't
create the slide they didn't create the

level of influence that you can have

if your culture supports making
decisions based on data what you should
you now have very simple very easy to
understand very plain as day data that

your ideas are back up for your

you want to have high availability of
